Dear Mr. McKeage:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.

Sincerely,
Stephanie Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CS210200969
Investigation #: 2022C0128017
Complaint Receipt Date: 12/21/2021
Investigation Initiation Date: 12/21/2021
Report Due Date: 02/19/2022
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Bay Pines Center
Facility Address: 2425 N. 30th Street
Escanaba, MI 49829
Facility Telephone #: (906) 789-1232
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1994
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 08/29/2020
Expiration Date: 08/28/2022
Capacity: 35
Program Type: CHILD CARING INSTITUTION, FIA
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
During a restraint, staff cut clothing off youth and put a blanket No
over youth due to youth's refusal to get into a safety gown.
Additional Findings:
Staff carried Youth from one room into another and then held her Yes
in the prone position while removing her clothing.
III. METHODOLOGY
12/21/2021 Special Investigation Intake 2022C0128017
12/21/2021 Special Investigation Initiated – Telephone with Program Manager
01/04/2022 Inspection Completed On-site Interview with Youth
01/10/2022 Contact - Face to Face Staff Interviews
01/13/2022 Contact - Face to Face Staff Interviews
01/26/2022 Contact - Face to Face Staff Interviews
01/28/2022 Contact - Telephone call received Staff Interview
01/31/2022 Contact - Face to Face Staff Interview
02/02/2022 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
01/31/2022 Pre-Exit Conference
ALLEGATION:
During a restraint, staff cut clothing off youth and put a blanket over youth due to
youth's refusal to get into a safety gown.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on January 4, 2022.
Administrator said the facility has a policy and procedure for removing youth’s
clothing when necessary. Administrator said Youth A has a lengthy history of
suicidal ideation and self-harm and the night in question was having suicidal actions.
Administrator said Supervisor called him and told him what had been occurring
throughout the evening and the current status of Youth A. Administrator said he
gave Supervisor permission to remove Youth A clothing and give her a safety gown
and safety blanket. Administrator said all paperwork was completed to document this
incident. Administrator said this was not the first time they needed to remove Youth
A’s clothing due to her suicidal actions.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on January 4, 2022. Youth A
said she has been placed at Bay Pines for about seven months and has had her
clothing cut off her body four times. Youth A said each time this has occurred the
staff working has asked her to change and she refuses. Youth A said staff will give
2

her several chances and about thirty minutes before removing her clothing. Youth A
said she is not allowed to keep anything on under the safety gown. Youth A said
both male and female staff will remove her clothing and it is always more than one
person in the room. Youth A said while removing her clothing they will have her
covered with a safety blanket and move it as they remove the clothing to keep her
fully covered. Youth A said the staff will then leave the room one at a time until
everyone is gone, and she then puts the safety gown on. Youth A said the removal
of her clothing triggers her as she was raped as a child. Youth A said staff will do
additional checks on her once she is placed in her safety gown. Youth A said it is not
common that it occurs and there is always a supervisor there when it has happened.
Youth A said she sees her therapist once per week but sometimes wishes she could
have additional therapy.
Supervisor was interviewed via TEAMS on January 10, 2022, and via telephone
on January 28, 2022. Supervisor said the night of 12/11/2021, Youth A had ripped
her shirt and underwear into long strips and had them hidden in her vagina.
Supervisor said Youth A was in her room and removed them and tied the strips of
clothing around her neck approximately six times. Supervisor said staff on the unit
had gone into Youth A’s room and cut the clothing off from around her neck.
Supervisor said Youth A was then asked to change into a safety gown and she
refused. Supervisor said Youth A was given about fifteen minutes and several
prompts to change however refused. Supervisor said she contacted Administrator
and he gave approval to cut off Youth A’s clothing and provide her with a safety
gown. Supervisor said she went into Youth A’s room and asked her once again to
change and she refused. Supervisor said she asked Youth A to move to another
room due to staff being unsure if Youth A had anything else hidden in her room to
self-harm with, however Youth A refused to move. Supervisor said Staff 1 entered
the room and put Youth A into a restraint hold and began to escort Youth A to the
new room. Supervisor said Youth A picked up her feet, so Staff 1 carried Youth A
into the new room. Supervisor said Staff 1 fell on top of Youth A and had his knee on
Youth A’s back and Supervisor directed Staff 1 to move immediately. Supervisor
said Youth A was face down on the floor and staff held her in this position while she
removed Youth A’s clothing. Supervisor said Youth A was covered with a safety
blanket while the clothing was removed so Youth A was not exposed. Supervisor
said Youth A was given a safety gown and all staff left her room so she could get up
and put on the gown. Supervisor said it is rare to have to remove youth’s clothing
however Youth A has been a difficult case with her self-harm and suicide attempts
and so they have done it more often with Youth A. Supervisor said the procedure is
to attempt to have the youth change themselves and if they do not and continue to
be a risk supervisors would contact Administrator to obtain permission to remove the
clothing. Supervisor said the process for removing the clothing was completed per
policy.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 31, 2022. Staff 1
said he has worked at Bay Pines since 8/23/2021. Staff 1 said he does not
remember all the details to the incident on 12/11/2021. Staff 1 said he was not in the
3

room when they removed Youth A’s clothing as he has never witnessed that before.
Staff 1 said he is aware that the decision to remove a youth’s clothing is done by a
supervisor. Staff 1 said it typically is with female youth so he would be in the unit
room while it is occurring in the bedroom, and he has helped hold a blanket up over
the doorway for privacy for a youth but never actually been in the room during the
removal of clothing.
Staff 2 was interviewed via TEAMS on January 10, 2022. Staff 2 said she has
worked at Bay Pines for about six months. Staff 2 said Youth A has daily issues of
self-harm. Staff 2 said Youth A will rip her clothing into long strips and then tie the
strips around her neck. Staff 2 said Youth A is usually very obvious with her self-
harm and will yell for staff. Staff 2 said staff will have to enter Youth A’s room to
remove the strips from her neck at which time Youth A usually becomes very
combative. Staff 2 said when Youth A is self-harming excessively or doing
something that is deemed more dangerous, she is asked to change into a safety
gown. Staff 2 said staff usually will give Youth A between fifteen minutes and one
hour to change her clothing. Staff 2 said several times Youth A has refused to
change her clothing and has had her clothing cut off and been given the safety gown
to put on. Staff 2 said all of the other youth are placed in their rooms and their
“blockers” are put down on their door window so they cannot see out of their rooms.
Staff 2 said a safety blanket is always placed over top of Youth A so she is never
exposed, and females will be the ones to remove Youth A’s clothing. Staff 2 said
there are times when male staff will have to hold Youth A’s legs however, they are
always facing away and never doing the cutting of the clothing. Staff 2 said when
Youth A is self-harming a supervisor is called to the unit to assist and then the
supervisor is the one to give the directive to the staff if they are allowed to remove
the clothing or not. Staff 2 said direct staff never make the decision to remove the
youth’s clothing.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Staff 3
said he was working on Youth A’s unit on 12/11/2021. Staff 3 said Youth A has
cycles of behaviors which can be days at a time. Staff 3 said Youth A will rip her
clothing into long strips and hid them in her vagina. Staff 3 said Youth A was in one
of her cycles and so staff were vigilant of all of her behaviors. Staff 3 said Youth A
made a “dummy” in her bed and then laid next to her door, so Staff 3 called Staff 2
to assist in doing a room check. Staff 3 said Staff 2 did a check in Youth A’s room
and Youth A had her face covered with a blanket and had labored breathing. Staff 3
said additional help was called and Staff 2 and Staff 3 went into Youth A’s room and
Staff 3 said he secured Youth A in a seated restraint and Staff 2 cut the fabric from
around Youth A’s neck. Staff 3 said he and Staff 2 then left the room only to notice a
few moments later Youth A had tied something else around her neck. Staff 3 said he
and Staff 2 went back into the room and removed the fabric again. Staff 3 said it was
then decided Youth A needed to move to a different room due to staff not being sure
if Youth A had anything else hidden in her room. Staff 3 said no one allowed Youth A
to change on her own and it was decided to remove her clothing which was
completed by Supervisor and Staff 2. Staff 3 said it is his understanding that in order
4

to cut a youth’s clothing off the supervisor of the shift needs to get permission from
Administrator and only female staff will remove female youth’s clothing, only male
staff will remove male youth clothing. Staff 3 said the removal of Youth A’s clothing
went “as smooth as possible”.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 26, 2022. Staff 4
said he was called into Youth A’s unit for assistance with her. Staff 4 said he held
Youth A’s ankles and Youth A was covered with a blanket while Supervisor removed
Youth A’s clothing. Staff 4 said he was facing away from Youth A in order to ensure
he did not see any part of Youth A’s body during the removal of the clothing.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on January 28, 2022. Staff 5 said he has
worked at Bay Pines since 11/8/2021. Staff 5 said he was on the unit with Youth A
on 12/11/2021. Staff 5 said Youth A had been having issues nightly with self-harm
and suicidal ideations. Staff 5 said when he arrived Staff 1 and Staff 3 were
escorting Youth A from her bedroom into another room. Staff 5 said once in the
other room Youth A was placed facing the ground and Staff 5 was holding her legs
as other staff removed Youth A’s clothing. Staff 5 said in order to cut a youth’s
clothing off the supervisor on shift has to get permission from Administrator. Staff 5
said staff never make that call alone.
Video Reviewed:
The video of Youth A’s incident was reviewed on January 13, 2022. Staff 4 is
standing in the doorway which blocks the view of the room so nothing can be seen
of Youth A’s clothes being removed.
Documents Reviewed:
 Youth A incident report from 3/25/2021 where her clothing was cut off due to
self-harm behavior.
 Youth A incident report from 3/31/2021 where her clothing was cut off due to
self-harm behavior.
 Youth A incident report from 4/16/2021 where her clothing was cut off due to
self-harm behavior.
 Youth A MiSACWIS incident report 127960182 dated 12/11/2021. The
incident report is consistent with staff interviews regarding Youth A’s self-
harm and removal of her clothing.
 Bay Pines Policy 630 Isolation and/or Confinement. This policy states the
following:
o It is not standard procedure to take youth clothing when a youth is in
isolation. When a youth is in isolation or is entering isolation, the
youth’s clothing are taken only when staff have a strong suspicion that
the youth is concealing a dangerous item (weapon, drugs, etc.) that
staff have been unable to detect with a pat-down search, or when the
youth has made repeated and genuine attempts to injure himself using
his clothing.
o When clothing must be taken, staff will:
5

 Allow the youth to remove and hand over his clothing. If the
youth refuses to remove and hand over his clothing, staff will
continue to maintain constant supervision until the youth
complies. Mechanical and/or physical restraint may be
continued along with constant supervision if needed to prevent
youth self-harm. Clothing will not be forcibly removed from youth
unless ordered by the Director, or the designated on-call
manager in the Director’s absence.
 Youth is issued a suicide blanket to wear instead of his clothing.
 Bay Pines Policy 503 – Suicide Precautions. This policy states the following:
o Removal of a youth’s clothing (excluding belts and shoelaces) is
avoided whenever possible. If clothing is removed, a safety smock or
other suicide resistant protective clothing must be provided.
 Bay Pines Standard Operating Procedure for Removing clothing from youth in
accordance with JRM policy 503. This procedure is consistent with the
descriptions given by staff in interviews. The procedure outlines that the youth
must be attempting to cause serious harm to self, staff must give youth an
opportunity to change themselves, blanket must cover youth during the
removal of clothing and the staff must provide the safety gown once clothing
is removed.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(2) At a minimum, the behavior management system shall
include all of the
following:
(b) Positive intervention strategies to assist residents in
developing improved problem solving, self-management,
and social skills.
(d) Written rules of conduct that specify all of the
following:
(i) Expected behavior.
(ii) Acts that are prohibited in the institution.
(iii) The range of interventions that may be imposed
for violation of those rules.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance with Behavior management
requirements. The staff followed the facility policy on removal of
Youth A’s clothing due to her continued self-harm. Supervisor
reported she had obtained permission from the Administrator,
who confirmed the conversation and reported he granted
permission.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
6

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Staff carried Youth from one room into another and the held her in the prone position
while removing her clothing.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Supervisor was interviewed via TEAMS on January 10, 2022, and via telephone
on January 28, 2022. Supervisor said the night of 12/11/2021, Youth A had ripped
her shirt and underwear into long strips and had them hidden in her vagina.
Supervisor said Youth A was in her room and removed them and tied the strips of
clothing around her neck approximately six times. Supervisor said staff on the unit
had gone into Youth A’s room and cut the clothing off from around her neck.
Supervisor said Youth A was then asked to change into a safety gown and she
refused. Supervisor said Youth A was given about fifteen minutes and several
prompts to change however refused. Supervisor said she contacted Administrator
and he gave approval to cut off Youth A’s clothing and provide her with a safety
gown. Supervisor said she went into Youth A’s room and asked her once again to
change and she refused. Supervisor said she asked Youth A to move to another
room due to staff being unsure if Youth A had anything else hidden in her room to
self-harm with, however Youth A refused to move. Supervisor said Staff 1 entered
the room and put Youth A into a restraint hold and began to escort Youth A to the
new room. Supervisor said Youth A picked up her feet, so Staff 1 carried Youth A
into the new room. Supervisor said Staff 1 fell on top of Youth A and had his knee on
Youth A’s back and Supervisor directed Staff 1 to move immediately. Supervisor
said Youth A was face down on the floor and staff held her in this position while she
removed Youth A’s clothing. Supervisor said Youth A was in the prone position for
less than four minutes. Supervisor said Youth A was covered with a safety blanket
while the clothing was removed so Youth A was not exposed. Supervisor said it is
not policy to carry youth and staff are not trained to carry youth. Supervisor said this
was the first and only time she has seen a staff carry a youth.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Staff 3
said he was working on Youth A’s unit on 12/11/2021. Staff 3 said Youth A has
cycles of behaviors which can be days at a time. Staff 3 said Youth A will rip her
clothing into long strips and hid them in her vagina. Staff 3 said Youth A was in one
of her cycles and so staff were vigilant of all of her behaviors. Staff 3 said Youth A
made a “dummy” in her bed and then laid next to her door, so Staff 3 called Staff 2
to assist in doing a room check. Staff 3 said Staff 2 did a check in Youth A’s room
and Youth A had her face covered with a blanket and had labored breathing. Staff 3
said additional help was called and Staff 2 and Staff 3 went into Youth A’s room and
Staff 3 said he secured Youth A in a seated restraint and Staff 2 cut the fabric from
around Youth A’s neck. Staff 3 said he and Staff 2 then left the room only to notice a
few moments later Youth A had tied something else around her neck. Staff 3 said he
and Staff 2 went back into the room and removed the fabric again. Staff 3 said it was
then decided Youth A needed to move to a different room due to staff not being sure
7

if Youth A had anything else hidden in her room. Staff 3 said he and Staff 1 went into
Youth A’s bedroom to escort her to another room. Staff 3 said he lost grip of Youth
A's arm and so Staff 1 picked up Youth A and carried her into the other room. Staff 3
said once Staff 1 got into the new room he was laying on top of Youth A and Youth A
was face down on the ground. Staff 3 said Youth A was on the ground face down for
sixty to ninety seconds. Staff 3 said Youth A was then transitioned by Staff 1 into a
seated restraint. Staff 3 said he then switched out with Staff 1 and held Youth A in
the seated position for about ten minutes and then Youth A was released due to
being deescalated. Staff 3 said no one allowed Youth A to change on her own and it
was decided to remove her clothing which was completed by Supervisor and Staff 2.
Staff 3 said the removal of Youth A’s clothing went “as smooth as possible” however
stated the restraint was not completed appropriately. Staff 3 said he felt Staff 1
should have waited when he had lost grip during the escort, and they could have
repositioned himself and assisted to move Youth A without having to carry her. Staff
3 said he has not seen any other staff carry youth at the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 26, 2022. Staff 4
said he was called into Youth A’s unit for assistance with her. Staff 4 said when he
arrived Staff 1 was in Youth A’s room and almost right away “scooped” Youth A up
and carried her to a new bedroom. Staff 4 said Staff 1 did not request any
assistance and just quickly carried Youth A to the new room. Staff 4 said Youth A
was placed on her “belly” with her head in the room first and feet in the doorway.
Staff 4 said he held Youth A’s ankles and Youth A was covered with a blanket while
Supervisor removed Youth A’s clothing. Staff 4 said he has participated in one other
carry with a youth at the end of December.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on January 28, 2022. Staff 5 said he has
worked at Bay Pines since 11/8/2021. Staff 5 said he was on the unit with Youth A
on 12/11/2021. Staff 5 said Youth A had been having issues nightly with self-harm
and suicidal ideations. Staff 5 said when he arrived Staff 1 and Staff 3 were
escorting Youth A from her bedroom into another room. Staff 5 said Staff 1 and Staff
3 were struggling to escort Youth A and Staff 3 lost grip and Staff 1 picked Youth A
up and carried her into the other room. Staff 5 said he did not hear Staff 1 asking for
any assistance and he seemed to pick her up as an impulse. Staff 5 said once in the
other room Youth A was placed facing the ground and Staff 5 was holding her legs
as other staff removed Youth A’s clothing. Staff 5 said he believes Youth A was
laying in the prone position for “less than five minutes”. Staff 5 said he has been
involved in a “few restraints” that led to staff carrying a youth. Staff 5 said failed
restraints or escorts seem to lead to staff just picking up the youth and carrying them
to where they need to be. Staff 5 said he was never trained in a “carry technique”.
Video Reviewed:
The video of Youth A’s restraint was reviewed on January 13, 2022. Youth A is
viewed being escorted out of a room with Staff 1 and Staff 3. Staff 3 is seen
releasing or losing his grip on Youth A’s arm at which time Staff 1 is seen picking up
Youth A off the ground in with his arms around her arms and chest and carrying her
8

into another room. Staff 1 is seen walking through the door, and it appears that
Youth A and Staff 1 go down to the ground however then Staff 4 moves into the
doorway which blocks the view of the room and the remainder of the restraint.
Documents Reviewed:
 Youth A MiSACWIS incident report 127960182 dated 12/11/2021. The
incident report is consistent with staff interviews regarding Youth A’s self-
harm and removal of her clothing. The incident report did not describe Youth
A being carried from one room to another but rather “escorted”. The incident
report did report Staff 1 and Youth A falling into the room however did not
report Youth A being in the prone position while the staff removed her
clothing.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
minor child’s behavior, chronological and developmental
age, size, gender, physical condition, medical condition,
psychiatric condition, and personal history, including any
history of trauma, and done in a manner consistent with the
resident’s treatment plan.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance with Resident restraint. In
interviews with Supervisor, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5 as well as
video review it is determined Staff 1 carried Youth A which is not
an approved escort or hold. In addition, Youth A was in the
prone position for a period of time when her clothing was
removed which is not a safe or approved position.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0102011 dated 3/10/2021 CAP approved 3/31/2021
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan no change be
made to the license status of this child caring institution.
